channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15292] Refined ZooKeeperWatcher to prevent ZooKeeper's callback while construction
item.description:
The existing code is not just messy but also contains a subtle bug of visibility due to missing synchronization between threads.

The root of the evil is that ZooKeeper uses a silly anti-pattern, starting a thread within its constructor, and in practice all the developers are not allowed to use ZooKeeper correctly without tedious code.
item.summary: Refined ZooKeeperWatcher to prevent ZooKeeper's callback while construction

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Added a patch. Sorry not tested. I hope it will work.
Added a revised patch; Sorry fixed wrong indents.

Added a revised patch; Added a test with extracting a testable part.

I just noticed that there was a chance to handle the anti-pattern when creating RecoverableZooKeeper, and it would be too late now to fix that without confusion.

This message was automatically generated.
FindBugs has denied my assertion itself straight on. When did he become so something?

+class InstancePending<T> {

Add javadoc and audience annotation to the class.


+      if (interrupted) {

+        Thread.currentThread().interrupt();

Call to Thread.currentThread().interrupt() can be performed inside the catch block - this would save variable interrupted.


+      instanceHolder = this.instanceHolder;

+      assert instanceHolder != null;

One way of calming findbugs is to use (instanceHolder != null) as condition for the while loop.


+class PendingWatcher implements Watcher {

Add javadoc and audience annotation to the class.
Actually can PendingWatcher be omitted ?
InstancePending is generic and the two methods PendingWatcher overrides are one-liner.

After the change, "hbase.zookeeper.watcher.sync.connected.wait" is dropped.
Should the loop in InstancePending#get() be passed a timeout so that the above config is still respected ?

Add javadoc and audience annotation to the class.

Audience annotations are for public classes, as their documentation. Non-public classes cannot be API and cannot break compatibility.
Javadoc might be useful so I'll try next week

Call to Thread.currentThread().interrupt() can be performed inside the catch block - this would save variable interrupted.

That is required to postpone the interruption at pendingLatch.await() inside the catch block, otherwise that method doesn't wait.

One way of calming findbugs is to use (instanceHolder != null) as condition for the while loop.

I'll try it

Actually can PendingWatcher be omitted ?
InstancePending is generic and the two methods PendingWatcher overrides are one-liner.

The thread safety of InstancePending is based on a subtle part of the Java Language Specification, in order to avoid slight overhead of synchronization. That is tricky and will be easily broken when someone edits, and it is better to encapsulate the concern into an independent class.

After the change, "hbase.zookeeper.watcher.sync.connected.wait" is dropped.
Should the loop in InstancePending#get() be passed a timeout so that the above config is still respected ?

No. PendingWathcer.prepare is expected to call immediately after its instantiation.
Moreover, the name of the property is wrong in actual fact; The existing code sleeps until just sharing the data without synchronization (and to make matters worse, sophisticated VM implementations might optimize and replace the variable references to null forever).

Actually can PendingWatcher be omitted ?

If you means embedding an anonymous class instead PendingWatcher, I think the code becomes a little messy, doesn't it?
Fine to keep the current form.

Added a revised patch;
Refactored to suppress the findbug warning, and added some javadoc (I hope there are not so wrong sentences or words

+1 overall

FYI It is already fixed by this patch but I just noticed that, it was more dangerous than what I thought. ZooKeeperWatcher sets many fields (which are effectively final) while constructing, and the variables had possibility not to be seen to other threads when the reference to the RecoverableZooKeeper instance is seen without synchronization.
NVM, that's wrong; Setting these parameters happens before starting the event thread.
